Summary: The scientific summary of the ECTRIMS conference highlights the need to reclassify multiple sclerosis (MS) as a virus instead of an autoimmune disease. Research shows that infection with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) may prime the immune system to accidentally attack a brain protein called Ano2, leading to MS. To cure and prevent MS, it is necessary to understand its origin and develop effective treatments. While EBV may be necessary but not sufficient to cause MS, there are many ways to cure diseases, and knowledge of the cause is not always necessary. The conference also explores topics such as the gut microbiome, biomarkers, potential future therapeutic targets, environmental, genetic, and epigenetic risk factors, and the relationship between EBV and MS.
Concept: Impact of Epstein-Barr Virus on the Immune System and Gut Health as Risk Factors for Diseases.
Title: Title: ECTRIMS Conference Highlights Need to Reclassify Multiple Sclerosis as a Virus

Summary: The recent advances in the diagnostic work-up of multiple sclerosis (MS), neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD), and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOGAD) were presented at the second patients community day of the European Committee for the Treatment and Research in Multiple Sclerosis (ECTRIMS) in Milan. The discussions covered differential diagnosis, the latest in therapy and biomarkers, and the role of hormones. The interview footage is available for viewing. Dr. Calvi presented the evolution of diffusivity measures within slowly expanding lesions (SELs) in MS. A multinational study on adult-onset leukodystrophies misdiagnosed or occurring with MS was also presented, which will be published soon. The attendees had the opportunity to ask the experts, and Andrew Solomon discussed complex MS differential diagnoses. The main mechanism of accumulation of disability in MS is progression independent of relapse activity (PIRS), which can predict MS progression. The room was packed for the first of two educational activities at MS Milan 23, which focused on imaging features of MOGAD and differential diagnosis with MS. The distinctive pathology in MS, MOGAD, and AQP4+NMO was highlighted in a captivating talk at MS Milan 23. Dr. Preziosa presented lesions/atrophy linked to worsened outcomes, accumulative disability (EDSS), and no single biomarker likely relapse onset in MS vs PPMS in early disease. Conventional MRI, chronic inflammation, and GM/spinal cord involvement in dx MS were also discussed. The proposed diagnostic criteria may not accurately distinguish MOGAD from MS, contributing to diagnostic inconsistencies across centers. MOG-IGG testing and consideration of MOGAD diagnosis are recommended only in the absence of better alternative causes, such as MS. The poster raising the issue of medical gaslighting in MS, written with , & Sleyman Gler, debuted at MS Milan 23.
Concept: Advancements in Mogad Diagnosis and Progression Understanding in Neurological Lesions

Summary: The European Congress of Neurology (ECN) in Milan provided more evidence for treating depression early after multiple sclerosis (MS) diagnosis. The progression of the disease is independent of disease activity, and the inflammation in the brain can cause depression. Proper MS management is important for mental health, and dietary management can delay the onset and manage already present comorbidities. Fatigue is a crucial topic in MS, and patient-reported measures are the gold standard. Sleep disorders have a significant impact on other MS symptoms, and cognitive rehabilitation or exercise may improve processing speed in individuals with progressive MS. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can help depression and anxiety in people with MS, and atrophy in the hippocampus and elevated cortisol can increase depression in MS. Adjustment to diagnosis and/or FX change can feel like being hit by a tornado, and the prevalence of mental health conditions in MS is 3-4 times higher than the general population.
Concept: Managing Depression, Fatigue, and Comorbidities: A Review of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Symptomatic Management

Summary: This recent study presented at the MS Milan conference showed improvements in cognitive biomarkers and mesenchymal stem cell therapy for patients with multiple sclerosis. The study used autologous mesenchymal stem cells and showed significant cognitive and biomarker improvements among patients with progressive multiple sclerosis receiving repeated intrathecal injections. The stimrouter neuromodulation system also showed promise in addressing lower urinary tract issues in multiple sclerosis. The study highlights the potential of stem cell therapy to repair neurological damage caused by multiple sclerosis.

Summary: The team at the University of Nottingham presented their research on functional brain dynamics in multiple sclerosis (MS) at the European Committee for Treatment and Research of Multiple Sclerosis (ECTRIMS) in Milan, Italy. The research focused on advanced ways of investigating how patterns of communication in the brain alternate and how these are affected by MS. The team presented their findings at the MS Milan event, which aims to ensure that information about MS research is accurately communicated to the MS community. The event is a big thanks to the European Committee for Treatment and Research of Multiple Sclerosis (ECTRIMS) for enabling the team to participate. The team's work is an important contribution to the MS community and highlights the importance of collaboration and networking in MS research.
Concept: Brain Date Congress - A Networking Opportunity for Researchers to Share Insights and Collaborate
Title: Title: "Functional Brain Dynamics in Multiple Sclerosis: Advanced Investigations and Collaborative Research at ECTRIMS Milan"

Summary: The three women presidents of the Great Milan Multiple Sclerosis Society shared their work at the MS Milan conference. The conference focused on new consensus statements on smoldering disease in multiple sclerosis. The women discussed their research on the degree of lymphopenia with siponimod and the predictability of which patients are more likely to experience grade 4 lymphopenia. They also discussed the use of biosimilar medications in multiple sclerosis and their potential to improve access to early high-efficacy treatment. The women emphasized the importance of global health in multiple sclerosis research and treatment.

Summary: This scientific summary highlights recent research in the field of multiple sclerosis (MS) that was presented at the MS Milan conference. The first study found that satralizumab continued to demonstrate long-term efficacy in patients with aqp4-igg seropositive non-motor symptomatic optic neuritis (NMSOD). The second study showed that ofatumumab held the line in patients with MS previously treated with anti-CD20 therapies. The summary also discusses breastfeeding recommendations in MS patients, family planning in women of childbearing age with MS, and the safety of anti-CD20 monoclonal antibodies in MS pregnancies. Additionally, the summary highlights new research on the use of biosimilar natalizumab and the evolving mindset in detection and treatment of MS, involving biomarkers and anti-CD20 therapies.

Summary: The dedication to advancements in multiple sclerosis research and patient care at MS Milan is truly remarkable. Bridging science and clinical practice is vital for improving health outcomes. However, clinical trials lack diversity, and current efforts to advance health equity via MS clinical trial participation are inadequate. Lack of inclusion and representation are obstacles to effectively understand safety, benefits, and treatment response across the MS population. MS Milan, thank you for joining us at MS Milan as we pave the way for advancements in multiple sclerosis research and patient care. We were excited to share our latest findings and deliver on our commitment to bridging science and clinical practice to drive better health outcomes for all. Patient-reported outcomes (PROMs) are a crucial topic at MS Milan, as capturing a person with MS's own changes is a practical, low-cost, high-potential way to track progression and efficacy of intervention. EC Trims presented data from the PH3 ULTIMATE I & II trials of Ublituximab in MS this week at MS Milan. The spotlight on young investigators has been an overwhelming success at MS Milan. The MS Milan patient community day is this Saturday, and we are eager to join with the MS community at MS Milan. We look forward to coming together with researchers, physicians, and advocates who share in our dedication to improving quality of life for people living with MS.

Summary: This work identifies a longitudinally stable autoantibody profile that is present before, during, and after the first symptom onset for a subset of individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study also discusses the role of the thalamus as a relay station and thalamic atrophy in MS. The speaker, Professor Stephen Hauser, gave an opening lecture at the MS Milan conference, discussing patterns of autoimmunity in different conditions and the potential implications for MS. The lecture also covered the genetic loci for MS susceptibility and severity, as well as the advancements in molecular medicine for MS. The speaker also presented new data at the conference reflecting the long-standing commitment to advancing the science in MS and improving the treatment experience for everyone living with the disease.
Concept: Stephen Hauser's research on autoantibodies and potential cure for autoimmune diseases.
